entry.title: Creating a correct map of Brazilian states with basemap date: 2013-08-12 12:45 comments: true slug: brazil-states-map
entry.summary:
This notebook was originally a post by Filipe Fernandes on python4oceanographers

basemap is an excelent tool, but its database lacks up-to-date information regarding the modern states boundaries in Brazil. This post is to show how to overcome that with an custom shapefile.

First of all we will need to download a proper shapefile. If you use openSUSE, my patch version of basemap already ships with file, and you'll find it at: '/usr/share/basemap/brazil'

In [1]: 
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from matplotlib.patches import Polygon
from mpl_toolkits.basemap import Basemap


def make_map():
    fig, ax = plt.subplots()
    m = Basemap(projection='merc', llcrnrlat=-35, urcrnrlat=7,
                llcrnrlon=-77, urcrnrlon=-32, resolution='i')
    m.ax = ax
    m.fillcontinents()
    return fig, m
    

def drawstates(ax, shapefile='/usr/share/basemap/brazil'):
        shp = m.readshapefile(shapefile, 'states', drawbounds=True)
        for nshape, seg in enumerate(m.states):
            poly = Polygon(seg, facecolor='0.75', edgecolor='k')
            ax.add_patch(poly)

Original basemap method to draw states:

In [2]: 
fig, m = make_map()
m.drawcountries()
m.drawstates()
Out[2]:
<matplotlib.collections.LineCollection at 0x3bf71d0>

Our custom shapefile:

In [3]: 
fig, m = make_map()
drawstates(m.ax)

See the difference?

This post was written entirely as an IPython notebook. The full notebook can be viewed statically (and downloaded) on nbviewer
